articles.title: UN refugee agency urges support to end displacement for millions of Syrians
articles.summary: The international community must support efforts towards peace and stability in Syria and end the displacement of millions – both within and outside the country – who fled years of war and just want to go home.
articles.content:
That’s the message from Kelly Clements, Deputy High Commissioner with the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, speaking on Tuesday after concluding a five-day visit to Lebanon and Syria.

“The international community cannot afford to be mere observers, assessing and judging the developments in Syria,” she said.

Tweet URL

“They must take an active role supporting stabilization and recovery efforts, helping Syrians rebuild and reshape their country.”

Homeward bound

More than 1.2 million people have returned to Syria since the fall of the Assad regime last December. Roughly 850,000 have crossed back from Lebanon and elsewhere in the region.

UNHCR has scaled up support to those choosing to return, including by providing money and transportation, to ensure the process is dignified and sustainable.

Meanwhile, returns continue inside Syria, with more than 1.7 million internally displaced people (IDPs), including just over 880,000 individuals who have departed from IDP sites in the north.

Commitment to cooperate

During her visit, Ms. Clements met with top government officials, refugees who have recently returned to Syria, and newly arrived refugees in Lebanon.

In meetings with Lebanese Prime Minister Nawaf Salam and other cabinet members, she expressed appreciation for continued generosity in hosting Syrian refugees and committed to further cooperation in supporting voluntary returns.

Since January, nearly 200,000 Syrian refugees have returned from Lebanon. Many more have indicated that they plan to follow in the coming months, especially after the authorities waived exit fees for those who overstayed their residency.

Ms. Clements also met a group of Syrian refugees who arrived in Lebanon in the past few months after fleeing recent violence back home.

“It's been a dynamic period where we see both Syrians returning, but also others becoming newly displaced,” she said.

“We count on the international community to continue supporting Lebanon and UNHCR’s work here,” she added. “Millions of Syrian refugees are still in neighbouring countries, and the world must not forget about them.”

Return and rebuild

In Syria, Ms. Clements met with Social Affairs Minister Hind Kabawat as well as the governors of Homs and Idleb. She also spoke to recently returned refugees who shared their hopes to rebuild their lives and their country.

“I saw up-close how people have preserved their will to return, stay and rebuild despite the harsh reality of destruction and lack of services following 14 years of war,” she said.

UNHCR and partners have expanded support to areas in Syria that are seeing high numbers of returns.

Ms. Clements visited rural Damascus and met returnees who received shelter assistance and support to start small businesses. She also helped inaugurate a newly habilitated civil registry office in Idleb governorate, which the agency supported.

She stressed that UNHCR and partners are on the ground in Syria doing their part, “but there is so much more to be done and the international community’s commitment to support such efforts is critical.”
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

articles.personality_title: UN calls for global support to help millions of displaced Syrians return home
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For more than a decade, millions of Syrians have been forced to leave their homes because of war. Many have fled to neighboring countries like Lebanon, living as refugees or displaced inside Syria.

**What happened** – Kelly Clements, Deputy High Commissioner of the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), visited Syria and Lebanon to see how people are returning home and rebuilding their lives. Since last December, over 1.2 million Syrians have returned to Syria, including about 850,000 from Lebanon. UNHCR is helping these returnees with money, transport, and support to make sure their return is safe and respectful.

**Impact** – This shows a strong effort to help Syrians go back to their country after years of conflict. The return of so many people is a sign that peace and stability may be growing. It also means Syrians can start rebuilding their communities and lives with help from UNHCR and local officials, even though many challenges remain.

**What's next step** – UNHCR and governments will continue working together to support more people who want to return. They are focusing on improving services, helping people find shelter, and creating jobs. The international community is urged to keep funding these efforts so the returns can be safe and lasting.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN is pushing for worldwide support to help millions of displaced Syrians safely return home and rebuild their lives after years of war.

**Contexte** – Depuis plus de dix ans, des millions de Syriens ont dû quitter leur foyer à cause de la guerre. Beaucoup ont fui vers des pays voisins comme le Liban, vivant comme réfugiés ou déplacés à l’intérieur de la Syrie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Kelly Clements, la Commissaire adjointe du Haut-Commissariat des Nations Unies pour les Réfugiés (HCR), a visité la Syrie et le Liban pour voir comment les personnes retournent chez elles et reconstruisent leur vie. Le HCR aide ces personnes avec de l’argent, des transports et un soutien pour que leur retour soit sûr et respectueux.

**Impact** – Cela montre un fort effort pour aider les Syriens à revenir dans leur pays après des années de conflit. Le retour de tant de personnes est un signe que la paix et la stabilité pourraient s’améliorer. Cela permet aussi aux Syriens de commencer à reconstruire leurs communautés et leurs vies avec l’aide du HCR et des autorités locales, même si beaucoup de défis restent à relever.

articles.title: Can prison inmates publish books? A denied publication took this discussion to Brazil’s Supreme Court
articles.summary: For members of the Brazilian Academy of Prison Letters, the case is about free speech: “After all, a prison sentence doesn’t strip the person from other fundamental rights.”
articles.content:
This article, written by Rafael Ciscati, was originally published on the Brasil de Direitos website on July 3, 2025. An edited version is republished on Global Voices under a partnership agreement.

It was the beginning of the 2010s, and Sagat B was serving time at a prison unit called Instituto Penal Vicente Piragibe in Rio de Janeiro, when he joined a project aimed at encouraging reading and writing within jail.

The project was developed by a non-governmental organization and included activities such as music classes and a sort of book club for a group of no more than seven inmates. Sagat, who had never finished reading a book in his entire life, was hooked by the proposal. After a week, he ran through the first book: ‘‘The Alienist’’ (1882), a Brazilian classic written by Machado de Assis (1839–1908).

Today, a free man, he has published his own memoir. In ‘‘The Criminal Who Became An Artist’’ (“O Bandido que virou artista,” 2022), Sagat B reflects on his life, and the message is significant: if it weren’t for the incentive to write, which he found while in prison, his path would be different. “Literature was essential to my resocialization,” he says.

That is why he follows closely and worries about the ongoing debate at the Federal Supreme Court (Supremo Tribunal Federal, STF) on the possibility of inmates being allowed to publish books.

The lawsuit that led to it originated in a case from 2019. An inmate from Campo Grande Federal Penitentiary, in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul, attempted to publish a book of over 1,000 pages, written while he was serving his sentence. The prison director didn’t authorize it. At the time, according to information presented before the court by the inmate's defense team, the director claimed he feared the manuscript could include encoded messages, addressed to criminal organizations. The material was subjected to analysis by the prison’s pedagogic team for three years.

The case was taken to court, which ultimately ruled in agreement with the director’s decision. Judges from the Federal Regional Court of the Fifth Region stated that the decision was supported by the Federal Prison System Handbook, a document that establishes procedures to be followed in maximum-security prisons.

In article 161, the handbook’s text says that: “Inmates are allowed to have their own literary production, such as writing biographies, poems, tales or other types, once it is authorised by the Federal Penitentiary’s administration, with the removal of the material or its dissemination being prohibited.”

With the first federal penitentiaries opening in 2006, the system hosts inmates who are deemed dangerous, in general, due to their links with criminal gangs. The handbook, which outlines procedures to be followed in these units, also establishes a series of restrictions.

“It is very focused on security and discipline,” says attorney Cátia Kim, general program coordinator at the Land, Work and Citizenship Institute (Instituto Terra Trabalho e Cidadania, ITTC).

To publish or not publish

Except for what the handbook states, no law or rule in Brazil forbids an inmate serving time from publishing what they write, according to experts consulted by Brasil de Direitos. “You start, therefore, from the basic principle that, if there is no prohibition, the practice is allowed,” states Kim.

This is the point being discussed at the Supreme Court: justices will decide if the restriction respects or not the Federal Constitution. For the defense representatives of the inmate/writer, this is a case of prior censorship, where the right of the author to free speech wasn’t respected.

Even if the case involves a person within the federal prison system, the justices’ ruling shall be extended to those serving time in regular prison units, under the state governments’ management.

State secretaries of penitentiary administration usually define rules that determine the daily lives of inmates in these units, notes Kim. “Decisions such as this one — regarding authorizing or not the publication of a book — are taken on a more executive level.”

As soon as he learned about the imbroglio at the Supreme Court, Sagat B sent a message to his peer Edson Souza Júnior. A lawyer and former inmate, like him, Souza is one of the members of the Brazilian Academy of Prison Letters (Academia Brasileira de Letras do Cárcere, ABLC).

Founded in 2024, the institution gathers inmates and former prisoners who have at least one published book. Sagat B and Souza, hold seats number 2 and 18, respectively.

Souza explains that the academy’s goal is “to defend literary production by inmates and former inmates,” adding that literature “is perhaps the sole instrument for resocialization available today.”

When he received Sagat B’s message, Souza had already learned about the lawsuit at the Supreme Court, and was preparing a petition requesting the academy to be included as “friend of the Court” (amicus curiae) — meaning, an entity capable of bringing important information for the suit. The request is still under consideration. If granted, the ABLC will defend before the Supreme Court inmates’ rights to have their writings published.

The Academy

The idea of creating an academy came from retired Judge Siro Darlan, who saw literature as a tool for transformation. The institution doesn't have a physical space; its members usually meet in video calls and participate in literary events in and out of prisons throughout Brazil.

As with the Brazilian Academy of Letters, members of the ABLC are elected by the other members. After that, they are selected to occupy chairs honoring noteworthy people who were in prison, including Russian writer Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821–1881), former Uruguayan president José ‘‘Pepe’’ Mujica (1935–2025) or the Brazilian modernist writer Patrícia Galvão, Pagu (1910–1962), a member of the Communist Party, imprisoned for taking part of a dockers’ strike in Santos port. Another communist writer, Jorge Amado (1912–2001), was arrested three times. Chair number 8 is named after him.

The ‘‘immortal’’ on Chair Number 1, named after writer Graciliano Ramos (1892–1953), is Márcio Nepomuceno, known as Marcinho VP, one of the leaders of the Red Command (Comando Vermelho), a major criminal organization in Brazil. Nepomuceno has four published books.

In prison since 1996, Nepomuceno also serves time within the federal system. Since 2024, he has been incarcerated at Campo Grande Penitentiary, which denied publishing rights to the inmate, which led to the Supreme Court discussion.

Souza says the difference between the two cases reveals how arbitrary the system can be. “No matter what the Handbook says, in practice, who decides if a person can publish or not is the director, and they don't need to justify their decision.”

The ban on publishing contradicts a resolution from 2021 by the National Council of Justice (CNJ), which promotes reading and participating in educational activities in exchange for a reduction in sentenced time. Projects such as these are still rare.

“Some states, such as São Paulo, Paraná, Espírito Santo and Paraíba, have been organizing literary contests, promoting the value of writing for the prison population,” says Marina Dias, executive director of the Defense Institute for Defense Rights (Instituto de Defesa dos Direitos de Defesa, IDDD). Others, she says, have prohibited the publishing of writings by inmates. “However, if one of the most powerful objectives of writing is to share, what is the purpose of encouraging this exercise under such conditions? Writing is a way of existing in this world. To deny the publication of something written is a form of erasure of people in prison.”

Dias notes that the Penal Execution Law (Lei de Execução Penal) guarantees to inmates the right to culture and education; therefore, it doesn't make sense to try to control what an inmate can and cannot write. “The official reason, the one saying the prohibition seeks maintenance of discipline and safety of penitentiaries, seems an excuse to keep a secrecy policy about what happens inside prisons.”

Members of the ABLC argue that the solution lies in respecting the right to freedom of expression.

“After all, a prison sentence doesn’t strip the person of other fundamental rights,” claims Souza. He acknowledges that, before publishing, texts can be submitted to pedagogical teams from the prison units. “But it’s necessary to establish a time limit to this analysis, and that the inmate’ lawyers can have access to it,” he says.

Sagat B, on the other hand, dreams further than that. He wishes to see a library composed only of books written by people who had been in prison: “Books that can talk about the reality inside prisons. If books like that existed, the book club in Vicente Piragibe wouldn’t have only seven participants. It would be more than 30,” he says, remembering the place where he became a reader.

articles.personality_title: Brazil’s Supreme Court debates if prisoners can publish their books
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Brazil, prisoners often write stories, poems, or books while serving their sentences. But whether they are allowed to publish these writings has been unclear. The question reached the country’s Supreme Court because some prison officials refused to let inmates publish their work, fearing security risks.

**What happened** – A case started in 2019 when an inmate from a federal prison tried to publish a book he wrote in jail. The prison director denied permission, worried the book might contain secret messages for criminals. The case went to court, which agreed with the prison. Now, Brazil’s Supreme Court is deciding if this restriction is allowed under the country’s Constitution.

**Impact** – This debate is important because writing helps prisoners change their lives and connect with the outside world. For example, Sagat B, once in jail, learned to read and write through a prison project and published his own memoir after release. The Brazilian Academy of Prison Letters, a group of inmates and former inmates who have published books, supports the right to publish. They say banning publication stops prisoners from sharing their stories and hurts their chances to rebuild their lives.

**What's next step** – The Supreme Court will decide if prisoners have the right to publish their writings freely or if security rules can block them. If the court supports inmates’ rights, more prisoners across Brazil might be able to share their stories. The Academy of Prison Letters is asking to help the court by explaining why this matters.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Brazil’s highest court is deciding if inmates can publish their writings, a case that could protect prisoners’ freedom of expression and support their rehabilitation.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Cour suprême du Brésil examine si les prisonniers peuvent publier leurs livres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au Brésil, les prisonniers écrivent souvent des histoires, des poèmes ou des livres pendant leur peine. Mais il est incertain s’ils ont le droit de publier ces écrits. Cette question est arrivée devant la Cour suprême du pays car certains responsables de prison refusent la publication, craignant des risques pour la sécurité.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2019, un détenu d’une prison fédérale a voulu publier un livre écrit en prison. Le directeur a refusé, craignant que le livre ne contienne des messages secrets pour des criminels. L’affaire est passée devant la justice, qui a donné raison à la prison. Maintenant, la Cour suprême décide si cette restriction est conforme à la Constitution.

**Impact** – Ce débat est important car l’écriture aide les prisonniers à changer leur vie et à garder un lien avec le monde extérieur. Par exemple, Sagat B, ancien détenu, a appris à lire et écrire grâce à un projet en prison et a publié ses mémoires après sa sortie. L’Académie brésilienne des Lettres de prison, un groupe d’anciens et d’actuels détenus ayant publié, soutient le droit de publier. Ils disent que l’interdiction empêche les prisonniers de raconter leurs histoires et nuit à leur réinsertion.

**Prochaine étape** – La Cour suprême décidera si les prisonniers ont le droit de publier librement ou si les règles de sécurité peuvent les en empêcher. Si la Cour donne raison aux détenus, plus de prisonniers au Brésil pourraient partager leurs histoires. L’Académie demande à aider la Cour en expliquant pourquoi c’est important.

**Phrase-clé** – La plus haute Cour du Brésil décide si les détenus peuvent publier leurs écrits, une affaire qui pourrait protéger leur liberté d’expression et soutenir leur réhabilitation.
articles.personality_title_es: La Corte Suprema de Brasil debate si los presos pueden publicar sus libros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Brasil, los presos a menudo escriben historias, poemas o libros mientras cumplen su condena. Pero no está claro si pueden publicar esos escritos. Esta pregunta llegó a la Corte Suprema porque algunos directores de prisiones negaron el permiso, por temor a riesgos de seguridad.

**Qué pasó** – En 2019, un preso de una cárcel federal intentó publicar un libro escrito en prisión. El director negó el permiso, preocupado de que el libro tuviera mensajes secretos para criminales. El caso fue a la justicia, que apoyó al director. Ahora, la Corte Suprema decide si esta restricción es válida según la Constitución.

**Impacto** – Este debate es importante porque escribir ayuda a los presos a cambiar sus vidas y a mantener contacto con el mundo exterior. Por ejemplo, Sagat B, antes preso, aprendió a leer y escribir gracias a un proyecto en la cárcel y publicó sus memorias tras salir. La Academia Brasileña de Letras de Prisión, un grupo de presos y ex presos con libros publicados, apoya el derecho a publicar. Dicen que prohibir la publicación impide que los presos cuenten sus historias y dificulta su reinserción.

**Próximo paso** – La Corte Suprema decidirá si los presos pueden publicar libremente o si las reglas de seguridad pueden impedirlo. Si la Corte falla a favor de los presos, más presos en Brasil podrán compartir sus historias. La Academia pidió participar para explicar por qué es importante.

**Frase clave** – La máxima corte de Brasil decide si los presos pueden publicar sus escritos, un caso que podría proteger su libertad de expresión y apoyar su rehabilitación.

articles.title: Eurobarometer: Youth in the EU are the biggest supporters of the Union’s enlargement
articles.content:
BRUSSELS – Young Europeans strongly support the EU enlargement – about two-thirds of respondents aged 15 to 39 believe that (potential) candidates should join the EU when they meet the necessary conditions, while 56 percent are in favor of further EU enlargement and believe it is beneficial for their country, according to the latest Eurobarometer survey published by the European Commission.

According to the survey respondents, the main advantages of EU membership enlargement are related to security and defense, a stronger economy and competitiveness, and the global influence of the EU in the world. However, 67 percent of EU citizens say they do not feel well informed about the enlargement. It is noted that surveys were conducted in candidate and potential candidate countries, and they generally show overall support for EU accession. In the Western Balkans, the highest support was recorded in Albania – 91 percent and North Macedonia – 69 percent, while the lowest was expressed in Serbia – 33 percent. In Georgia and Ukraine, support is 74 and 68 percent, respectively. It is added that the survey showed that Albanians have the most positive image of the EU (82 percent), while in Serbia that percentage is the lowest (38 percent).

In Moldova, more than half of its citizens have a positive image of the EU (55 percent), while that number is lower in Ukraine (49 percent) and Georgia (43 percent). In Turkey, a similar survey showed support for EU membership at 49.9 percent, while 50.7 percent of citizens view the EU positively. It is stated that the survey results can help the Commission’s efforts to engage the public both in the EU and in candidate and potential candidate countries about the EU enlargement policy, as well as the Commission’s work on how to better communicate the progress made. The survey was conducted live between February and June 2025. (September 2)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on broad public support among youth and citizens in various countries for EU enlargement, which promotes peace, security, economic cooperation, and democratic values across a large region. This has significant positive societal impact by fostering unity and stability in Europe and its neighbors. The survey provides detailed insights into public opinion, supporting informed policy and communication efforts by the European Commission. The scope and substance are meaningful and focused on a single topic.
articles.personality_title: Young Europeans show strong support for EU enlargement, survey finds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) is a group of countries in Europe that work together on many issues like trade, security, and laws. Some countries want to join the EU, but they must meet certain conditions first. Understanding what people think about this enlargement helps the EU plan better.

**What happened** – A survey called the Eurobarometer was done by the European Commission between February and June 2025. It asked people aged 15 to 39 across the EU and candidate countries about their views on EU enlargement. About two-thirds of young people support adding new members when they meet the rules. Overall, 56 percent of young respondents believe that growing the EU is good for their country. The survey also included countries wanting to join, like Albania and North Macedonia, which showed high support, while Serbia had lower support.

**Impact** – This survey is important because it shows that many young people see benefits in EU enlargement, such as better security, stronger economies, and more influence around the world. It also reveals that many citizens feel they don’t have enough information about the process. This clear picture of public opinion helps the EU communicate better and plan how to include new members successfully.

**What's next step** – The European Commission will use these survey results to improve how it talks to people about EU enlargement. This means sharing more information and explaining progress clearly. The survey also encourages continued discussions with candidate countries to support their journey toward joining the EU.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Most young Europeans support EU enlargement, seeing it as a way to improve security, economy, and global influence, while also calling for better information on the process.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les jeunes Européens soutiennent fortement l’élargissement de l’UE, selon un sondage
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) est un groupe de pays européens qui collaborent sur des sujets comme le commerce, la sécurité et les lois. Certains pays souhaitent rejoindre l’UE, mais doivent d’abord remplir certaines conditions. Comprendre l’opinion des citoyens aide l’UE à mieux planifier.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un sondage appelé Eurobaromètre, réalisé par la Commission européenne entre février et juin 2025, a interrogé des jeunes de 15 à 39 ans dans l’UE et les pays candidats. Environ deux tiers des jeunes soutiennent l’adhésion de nouveaux membres quand les règles sont respectées. Au total, 56 % des jeunes pensent que l’élargissement est bénéfique pour leur pays. Le sondage a aussi inclus des pays candidats comme l’Albanie et la Macédoine du Nord, où le soutien est élevé, tandis que la Serbie montre un soutien plus faible.

**Impact** – Ce sondage est important car il montre que beaucoup de jeunes voient des avantages à l’élargissement de l’UE, comme une meilleure sécurité, une économie plus forte et plus d’influence dans le monde. Il révèle aussi que beaucoup de citoyens se sentent mal informés sur le sujet. Ces résultats aident l’UE à mieux communiquer et à préparer l’accueil de nouveaux membres.

**Prochaine étape** – La Commission européenne utilisera ces résultats pour mieux informer les citoyens sur l’élargissement. Cela signifie partager plus d’informations et expliquer clairement les avancées. Le sondage encourage aussi à poursuivre les discussions avec les pays candidats pour les aider à rejoindre l’UE.

**En une phrase** – La majorité des jeunes Européens soutient l’élargissement de l’UE, le voyant comme un moyen d’améliorer la sécurité, l’économie et l’influence mondiale, tout en demandant une meilleure information sur le processus.
articles.personality_title_es: Los jóvenes europeos apoyan firmemente la ampliación de la UE, según encuesta
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) es un grupo de países en Europa que trabajan juntos en temas como comercio, seguridad y leyes. Algunos países quieren unirse a la UE, pero deben cumplir ciertas condiciones primero. Conocer la opinión de las personas ayuda a la UE a planificar mejor.

**Qué pasó** – Una encuesta llamada Eurobarómetro, hecha por la Comisión Europea entre febrero y junio de 2025, preguntó a jóvenes de 15 a 39 años en la UE y países candidatos sobre su opinión sobre la ampliación de la UE. Cerca de dos tercios de los jóvenes apoyan que nuevos miembros se unan cuando cumplan las reglas. En total, el 56 % piensa que la ampliación es buena para su país. La encuesta también incluyó países candidatos como Albania y Macedonia del Norte, que mostraron mucho apoyo, mientras que Serbia tuvo menos apoyo.

**Impacto** – Esta encuesta es importante porque muestra que muchos jóvenes ven beneficios en la ampliación de la UE, como mejor seguridad, economías más fuertes y más influencia en el mundo. También revela que muchos ciudadanos sienten que no tienen suficiente información sobre el proceso. Esta información clara ayuda a la UE a comunicar mejor y planear cómo incluir nuevos miembros con éxito.

**Próximo paso** – La Comisión Europea usará estos resultados para mejorar cómo informa a las personas sobre la ampliación de la UE. Esto significa compartir más información y explicar claramente los avances. La encuesta también anima a continuar las conversaciones con los países candidatos para apoyarlos en su camino hacia la adhesión.

**En una frase** – La mayoría de los jóvenes europeos apoyan la ampliación de la UE, viéndola como una forma de mejorar la seguridad, la economía y la influencia global, y piden mejor información sobre el proceso.

articles.title: Costa started a tour in Slovenia through the capitals of the EU
articles.summary: President of the European Council Antonio Costa has started a tour of EU member states in Slovenia. Slovenian Prime Minister Robert Golob stated that Slovenian exporters can be satisfied with the EU-US trade agreement.
articles.content:
President of the European Council Antonio Costa has started a tour of EU member states in Slovenia. Slovenian Prime Minister Robert Golob stated that Slovenian exporters can be satisfied with the EU-US trade agreement.

Cerklje na Gorenjskem – The largest Slovenian exporters can be satisfied with the trade agreement concluded in July between the EU and the USA, said Slovenian Prime Minister Robert Golob after a meeting with the President of the European Council Antonio Costa at Strmol Castle. Costa, who started a three-week tour of EU member states in Slovenia, emphasized that the framework agreement with the USA should be viewed in a broader context, particularly regarding the Russian aggression against Ukraine.

“Our largest exporters can be somewhat satisfied with what has been achieved, as their competitive position is not significantly deteriorating. They might even gain some opportunities,” Golob said about the implications of the trade agreement between the EU and the USA for the Slovenian economy.

The agreement, which limits tariffs on imports of the vast majority of goods from the EU to the USA to 15 percent, also includes two of the most sensitive sectors relevant to Slovenian exports to the USA, he explained. These are the automotive and pharmaceutical industries.

“The European Union has managed to negotiate tariffs that are among the best, if not the best, of all countries that have been exposed to tariffs from the United States so far,” Golob assessed the agreement between Brussels and Washington.

Costa, meanwhile, emphasized that the agreement should be placed in the broader context of relations with the USA, particularly their support for Ukraine in the Russian aggression.

At the beginning of his tour of the capitals of member states, which he embarked on in preparation for the upcoming European Council meetings, he also highlighted Slovenia’s important role on the international stage. Among other things, he stated that Slovenia is taking a leading role in efforts to protect people and end the war in Gaza.

The Slovenian Prime Minister announced that Slovenia, together with a few like-minded countries, will take some concrete steps in the coming weeks to pressure the Israeli government to stop the massacre in Gaza. (September 2)
articles.reasoning: The article highlights positive diplomatic efforts by EU leaders to strengthen trade relations with the USA, which benefits exporters and economies broadly. Additionally, it emphasizes Slovenia's leadership role in international humanitarian efforts to protect people and end the war in Gaza, which has significant human rights implications.
articles.personality_title: EU Council president starts tour in Slovenia highlighting trade and peace efforts
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Antonio Costa, the President of the European Council, began a tour of European Union (EU) member states in Slovenia. This tour comes as EU countries prepare for upcoming important meetings.

**What happened** – During his visit, Costa met with Slovenian Prime Minister Robert Golob at Strmol Castle. They discussed the new trade agreement between the EU and the United States, which was signed in July. Golob said that Slovenia’s largest exporters are generally happy with the agreement because it keeps trade tariffs low, especially for cars and medicines.

**Impact** – This trade deal is important because it limits tariffs on most goods from the EU to the US to 15 percent. For Slovenia, this means its exporters can compete better and might even find new opportunities. Costa also pointed out that this agreement is part of a bigger relationship between the EU and the US, including their support for Ukraine in the conflict with Russia.

**What's next step** – Costa will continue visiting other EU capitals as part of his tour. Meanwhile, Slovenia plans to take action with other countries to push Israel to stop violence in Gaza. This shows Slovenia’s growing role in international peace efforts.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s new trade deal with the US supports Slovenian exporters while Slovenia leads diplomatic efforts to promote peace.
